title: Mod challenge: find me ten good PB threads from ten permabanned players
body:
A permaban for a toxic player indicates that Riot no longer believes that player capable of reform. Punishments didn't prompt self-reflection, warnings of losing the account were ignored, all the toxic behavior was rationalized with a variety of terrible arguments. Did more than four punishments do the trick for some people? Yes, but this was very infrequent, and not worth the damage caused by all the consistently toxic players who didn't learn and were allowed to keep playing. Riot doesn't believe a permabanned player will improve, and they're not interested in letting them try. Riot wants those players to leave.

These people who are unable to follow rules and behave themselves then go onto the Boards and start insisting that their ban was unjust, and any other player's permaban was unjust, and the number of reports matters, and someone else started it, and so on. When someone disagrees with them, they start to demonstrate why they got a permaban in the first place: poor behavior. They pollute the place with bad ideas, bad advice, and uncivil discourse. Sometimes permabanned players post on each other's threads to show support for misbehavior, like a bunch of convicts banging their tin cups against the bars. What's the point of discussing their ban, anyway? It's permanent, and Riot wants those people to quit the game.

Even now there is a highly-upvoted thread on the front page about how permabans for toxic chat are bad because permabanned players just make new accounts anyway, and how a clever and novel solution would be... stacking chat restrictions. This was posted, of course, by a player who was permabanned for toxic chat and isn't happy about being punished. They have no problem with breaking the rules and annoying people; they just don't like it when something bad happens to _them_. Note that most permabanned players don't keep playing, and Riot tried stacking chat restrictions but it didn't work and just produced more toxic behavior that was more difficult to detect. The thread is selfish and poorly-researched. And yet, it has tons of upvotes, currently at 71-24, with a poll at 179-59. But you look at the comments and see half a dozen players - all relentlessly toxic and permabanned - insisting that this is a good idea and they shouldn't have been permabanned and it was a setup and it was all the other guy's fault and so on and so on with all the same trash they always spew because they're basically sociopaths. Harsh, but I'm not mincing words here. And most of them say they have a giant pile of smurf accounts. Now let's do some math: a few toxic players multiplied by a giant pile of smurf accounts each... what do you know! That's how many upvotes this thread has. It's an obvious example of vote manipulation, bringing a demonstrably useless thread (the idea has been tried and proven ineffective, remember) to the forefront.

This brings us to my challenge to mods. Genesis 18-19 is the well-known story about the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. Abraham convinced God to spare these sinful cities if they contained a mere ten righteous people. Unfortunately, there weren't any, and the cities were destroyed.

If you can find me ten separate Player Behavior threads by ten separate permabanned players where the player asked about their ban, behaved themselves, learned, thanked respondents for teaching them the error of their ways, improved their behavior, reformed, and became an upstanding player/member of the community (flying in the face of Riot's real-world data, mind you), then I will at least be willing to entertain the idea that perhaps those extraordinary cases are worth the absolutely massive amount of chaff. We're paying a cost, so there should be _some_ benefit. But if you can't, then I urge you to stop allowing permabanned toxic assholes to trash that Board, and just instantly delete any thread or comment in PB posted by a permabanned player. Don't permaban them from Boards entirely; just remove anything they post in PB.

Note that I'm not just talking about threads that weren't quite bad enough for mods to lock/delete, because that almost never happens even when it obviously should. I'm talking about threads that are _actually good and useful_ from permabanned players.

If nothing else, the time period covered by ten such posts should show us how often we see such a chimera around here, and perhaps make a case for much stricter moderation on low-quality content from players who are already known to specialize in such.

Ten separate threads, ten separate permabanned players, ten separate success stories.

replies.body:
1. [A player who got a permanent ban while on a 14-day ban posts a reasonable thread inquiring about it.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/tBosTUOx-getting-perma-banned-while-being-on-week-2-of-your-14-day-suspencion)
2. [A player with 31 banned accounts legitimately seeks help with how to manage his mental state in games.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/fQBqp9Aj-hi-guys-help-me-to-reform.)
3. [A player puzzled about a permanent ban takes feedback gracefully](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/2kzo6li8-should-i-be-permanently-banned)
4. [A player with 5+ banned accounts finally reaches Honor 3 and feels great about it.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/Ur9ZnTZG-it-finally-happened)
5. [A player makes a heartfelt apology to the community and seems to have learned a lesson.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/JAEW1pGm-an-open-apology-to-the-community-and-riot-games)
6. [A player apologizes and uses himself/herself as a warning to others that the cost of losing your account/progress isn't worth the price.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/KYUeQk5E-thank-you-for-the-memories-riot-games-im-sorry-i-couldnt-improve-and-be-less-toxic-please-read)
7. [A player realizes their ban was justified and their multiple tickets to Riot were the result of anger and obsession, and makes a public apology.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/zO7qY297-a-public-apology-to-riot-games)
8. [A player with multiple accounts banned and a punishment on the current one manages to get back to Honor 1, and feels great about it.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/p8tiQWAh-so-proud-of-myself)
9. [A player acknowledges their own problems and looks for a space to put their thoughts to text and get some helpful feedback.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/E7v0mV7b-my-5th-account-why-it-may-get-banned-in-a-few-days-and-my-feelings-on-it)
10. [Removed] Apologies -- this last one didn't meet your specific criteria for a perma-banned player showing reform upon my second check, but I can't be bothered to use the awkward tools at my disposal (see below) to keep looking, because I feel at this point I've proven it sufficiently.

--------------------------------------

The only reason this was *remotely* tricky is that there isn't a way to check from the thread title if a player is banned or not (and some players don't mention if they were ever banned), and the **TOP** post option is no longer on **Player Behavior**. If it weren't for those two factors this would have taken less than the 10 minutes or so it actually took.

> 1. [A player who got a permanent ban while on a 14-day ban posts a reasonable thread inquiring about it.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/tBosTUOx-getting-perma-banned-while-being-on-week-2-of-your-14-day-suspencion)

[A player apologizes and uses himself/herself as a warning to others that the cost of losing your account/progress isn't worth the price.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/KYUeQk5E-thank-you-for-the-memories-riot-games-im-sorry-i-couldnt-improve-and-be-less-toxic-please-read)

> 10. [Removed] Apologies -- this last one didn't meet your specific criteria for a perma-banned player showing reform upon my second check, but I can't be bothered to use the awkward tools at my disposal (see below) to keep looking, because I feel at this point I've proven it sufficiently.
> 
> --------------------------------------
> 
> The only reason this was *remotely* tricky is that there isn't a way to check from the thread title if a player is banned or not (and some players don't mention if they were ever banned), and the **TOP** post option is no longer on **Player Behavior**. If it weren't for those two factors this would have taken less than the 10 minutes or so it actually took.

0. a month ago
0. deleted
0. two months ago
0. two months ago
0. three months ago
0. three months ago
0. four months ago
0. five months ago
0. six months ago
0. none

Eight in six months.

I will assume that the deleted one was deleted because the OP had a very good, non-toxic reason for removing it, not because it was a toxic thread removed by a mod.

I'll substitute the first thread suggested by Umbral Regent [below](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/community-moderation/qjasOEbd-mod-challenge-find-me-ten-good-pb-threads-from-ten-permabanned-players?comment=00030000) for number 10.

I suppose this is just barely enough to almost count with the assumption and the substitution. Let's table that brimstone. :D

However, PB is still a cesspool, and I stand by that observation.

P.S.: Any plans on removing/locking that vote-botted thread?

> [{quoted}](name=KFCeytron,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:24:34.895+0000)Eight in six months.

[Second one was a link error rather than a deletion](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/fQBqp9Aj-hi-guys-help-me-to-reform), so that's 9 in six months, found in ten minutes using a bad search interface. I have neither the time nor the desire to further prove what I know to be true to you. You are also welcome move the goalposts of your original request by including timelines or assuming I picked everything in chronological order rather if you like (rather than primarily basing my search on upvoted threads with reasonable titles to save myself time spent reading), but the fact is that permanently banned players *do* make good threads and have success stories.

> P.S.: Any plans on removing/locking that vote-botted thread?

I don't know what thread you're talking about myself, and typically vote-botting is something that is both hard to confirm and rarely actually worth stepping in unless it's causing a real problem.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=000300010000,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:27:29.459+0000)
>
> [Second one was a link error rather than a deletion](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/fQBqp9Aj-hi-guys-help-me-to-reform), so that's 9 in six months, found in ten minutes using a bad search interface. You can make excuses if you like, but the fact is that permanently banned players *do* make good threads and have success stories.
> 
> I don't know what thread you're talking about myself, and typically vote-botting is something that is both hard to confirm and rarely actually worth stepping in unless it's causing a real problem.

??

I'm not making excuses. I assumed that it worked. But now that I can visit the link, I counter that that was not a good example of a positive thread. The OP is a child (15) who has over 30 permabans and yet believes that all their misbehavior is the game's fault because they're a fantastic person who gets little social interaction and is "prone to snappping at people who provoke [them]" but only rages in game because "when [the] jungler is truly useless" it provokes "provokes [their] flaming." I was in that thread. It was not positive. There was no growth, only denial and severe RL social issues.

Vote-botted "stacking chat restrictions are the answer" thread: https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/7RTLWEuK-an-long-essay-on-permabans-one-size-fits-all-policies-dont-work

> [{quoted}](name=KFCeytron,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=0003000100000000,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:37:01.173+0000)There was no growth, only denial and severe RL social issues.

How you react to a player matters. My own interaction with the OP in that thread was one where, to me, it seemed the OP took the feedback. Pushing back slightly is both allowed and a part of growth. The player asked for in-game advice, and so I provided in-game advice. It's not really our place to assume, as you suggested, "You don't need League-specific advice; you need skills and strategies to help you cope with other people who may or may not meet your expectations, because everyone needs to deal with that throughout their life, at least occasionally."

> Vote-botted "stacking chat restrictions are the answer" thread: https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/7RTLWEuK-an-long-essay-on-permabans-one-size-fits-all-policies-dont-work

I'm not convinced that's a vote-botted thread (it's surprisingly well presented for suggestions like that, and could also simply have been shared other places). As the discussion doesn't seem overly problematic (save a few comments I believe are in the report queue), I don't think there's much to be gained from assuming manipulation and locking it.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=00030001000000000000,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:54:24.186+0000)
>
> How you react to a player matters. My own interaction with the OP in that thread was one where, to me, it seemed the OP took the feedback. Pushing back slightly is both allowed and a part of growth. The player asked for in-game advice, and so I provided in-game advice. It's not really our place to assume, as you suggested, "You don't need League-specific advice; you need skills and strategies to help you cope with other people who may or may not meet your expectations, because everyone needs to deal with that throughout their life, at least occasionally."
> 
> I'm not convinced that's a vote-botted thread (it's surprisingly well presented for suggestions like that, and could also simply have been shared other places). As the discussion doesn't seem overly problematic (save a few comments I believe are in the report queue), I don't think there's much to be gained from assuming manipulation and locking it.

So, feedback that fed OP's confirmation bias was positive and good, while my feedback that didn't was bad? I didn't assume anything. OP flat-out said that they rarely have social interactions, and when they do they tend to snap at people. That's a pretty clear issue not limited to League. And yet, OP thinks that League is the problem because their RL behavior is fine.

Man, there are like half a dozen commenters, half of them saying "this is a bad idea because it's been proven not to work," and the other half saying "my 20 permabanned accounts and I think this is genius." It's not hard to put two and two together. If I was a mod, voting on that thread would've been locked in the first few minutes after it got its initial pile of votes.

> [{quoted}](name=KFCeytron,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=000300010000000000000000,timestamp=2019-08-27T14:06:25.629+0000)So, feedback that fed OP&'s confirmation bias was positive and good, while my feedback that didn't was bad?

Not necessarily. More that feedback that a player isn't ready to hear can often cause them to push back more, and it's not really our job to play therapist to players unless that's what they request.

> ~~A banned player presents a straight-forward and respectfully presented argument for a change to the system.~~ Apologies -- this last one doesn't meet your specific criteria for a perma-banned player showing reform, but I can't be bothered to use the awkward tools at my disposal (see below) to keep looking, because I feel at this point I've proven it sufficiently.

I've got at least one example of a permabanned player showing reform, alongside one case of a permabanned player generally accepting their punishment and putting forward a worthwhile discussion despite it.

10) [A player opens a discussion following their second permanent ban, asking the community for tips and advice on how to avoid tilting, flaming, and controlling anger.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/s7Qql6wH-any-reformed-players-here)

And for bonus points, [a permabanned player suggesting changes to the punishment system - not perfect, but still a positive discussion.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/56LXnOrq-suggestions-for-policy-changes-in-regards-to-permabanning-accounts)

> [{quoted}](name=Umbral Regent,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:10:44.246+0000)
>
> I've got at least one example of a permabanned player showing reform, alongside one case of a permabanned player generally accepting their punishment and putting forward a worthwhile discussion despite it.
> 
> 10) [A player opens a discussion following their second permanent ban, asking the community for tips and advice on how to avoid tilting, flaming, and controlling anger.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/s7Qql6wH-any-reformed-players-here)
> 
> And for bonus points, [a permabanned player suggesting changes to the punishment system - not perfect, but still a positive discussion.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/56LXnOrq-suggestions-for-policy-changes-in-regards-to-permabanning-accounts)

I'll take that ten as a replacement for The Djinn's missing tenth.

The bonus point is not only imperfect, it's a flat-out "no." Threads from permabanned players who want to keep interacting with the community they've been permanently banned from for a chance to "prove" themselves when they already had several such chances are a dime a dozen. Every time Riot actually gives something like that the benefit of the doubt and tries it, it blows up in their face as the permabanned toxic players who are allowed back into their accounts quickly return to their old habits (hence the reason that they were permabanned in the first place).

> The bonus point is not only imperfect, it's a flat-out "no." Threads from permabanned players who want to keep interacting with the community they've been permanently banned from for a chance to "prove" themselves when they already had several such chances are a dime a dozen. Every time Riot actually gives something like that the benefit of the doubt and tries it, it blows up in their face as the permabanned toxic players who are allowed back into their accounts quickly return to their old habits (hence the reason that they were permabanned in the first place).

The point of the bonus thread was that permabanned players, even with shortsighted or hopeful suggestions that would allow permabanned players back, can still create worthwhile topics of discussion. Riot needn't really consider their suggestions, but the fact remains that even with unrepentant suggestions that try to enable toxic players to return after a permaban, there can still be some worthwhile stuff to discuss.

Which, in my opinion, is even more reason to allow permabanned players their voice on PB. There may certainly be a lot of the same suggestions tossed about, but there's always a chance that something interesting will crop up.

> [{quoted}](name=Umbral Regent,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=0003000000010000,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:40:44.729+0000)
>
> The point of the bonus thread was that permabanned players, even with shortsighted or hopeful suggestions that would allow permabanned players back, can still create worthwhile topics of discussion. Riot needn't really consider their suggestions, but the fact remains that even with unrepentant suggestions that try to enable toxic players to return after a permaban, there can still be some worthwhile stuff to discuss.
> 
> Which, in my opinion, is even more reason to allow permabanned players their voice on PB. There may certainly be a lot of the same suggestions tossed about, but there's always a chance that something interesting will crop up.

That wasn't a discussion. It was an echo chamber. I still think that kid needs to discuss their issues with their parents.

Some discussions and voices are good to have at least once... but not more than once. There's a reason I now have a copypasta file to respond to PB threads.

> That wasn't a discussion. It was an echo chamber. I still think that kid needs to discuss their issues with their parents.

I have a feeling we're talking about two separate threads here. The "bonus point" thread may have had some generally bad ideas (largely due to them orienting around overturning permabans), but it wasn't really an echo chamber. The OP only really participated in one comment string, and seemed both amicable and willing to accept disagreement.

> Some discussions and voices are good to have at least once... but not more than once. There's a reason I now have a copypasta file to respond to PB threads.

I should point you, then, to the [Player Behavior Board Rules](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/OjEUxbwH-player-behavior-rules-update).

> **Don't Be a Robot**
>
> We see a lot of the same questions over and over in Player Behavior, which leads to the habit of copy/paste answers. Responding to people in this way can feel cold and dismissive. If you choose to use scripts, you should also include something that is specific to that request.

I've noticed your C/P responses, and while I haven't personally read through the bulk of them to see if there was anything _non_-C/P about them, it's still worth pointing out that those should be avoided.

It's good to be prepared for any occasion and all, but there's a point where being prepared can become detrimental to the quality of discussion on the board.

> [{quoted}](name=Umbral Regent,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=000300000001000000000000,timestamp=2019-08-27T14:01:05.872+0000)
>
> I have a feeling we're talking about two separate threads here. The "bonus point" thread may have had some generally bad ideas (largely due to them orienting around overturning permabans), but it wasn't really an echo chamber. The OP only really participated in one comment string, and seemed both amicable and willing to accept disagreement.
> 
> I should point you, then, to the [Player Behavior Board Rules](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/OjEUxbwH-player-behavior-rules-update).
> 
> I've noticed your C/P responses, and while I haven't personally read through the bulk of them to see if there was anything _non_-C/P about them, it's still worth pointing out that those should be avoided.
> 
> It's good to be prepared for any occasion and all, but there's a point where being prepared can become detrimental to the quality of discussion on the board.

I see. That's a stupid rule, because the same questions deserve the same answers and there's no need to waste time rewriting it every time. It's better than "PB bingo," anyway, which is the reason I started using C/P in the first place. Seemed a lot more useful. I will be making a thread about that shortly, although I'm sure it will be downvoted by players who feel that just because they called their teammates braindead idiots five games in a row doesn't mean they don't deserve hours of someone's time.

> [{quoted}](name=Umbral Regent,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2019-08-27T13:10:44.246+0000)
>
> I've got at least one example of a permabanned player showing reform, alongside one case of a permabanned player generally accepting their punishment and putting forward a worthwhile discussion despite it.
> 
> 10) [A player opens a discussion following their second permanent ban, asking the community for tips and advice on how to avoid tilting, flaming, and controlling anger.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/s7Qql6wH-any-reformed-players-here)
> 
> And for bonus points, [a permabanned player suggesting changes to the punishment system - not perfect, but still a positive discussion.](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/56LXnOrq-suggestions-for-policy-changes-in-regards-to-permabanning-accounts)

Thanks for the tag-in!

> If you can find me ten separate Player Behavior threads by ten separate permabanned players where the player asked about their ban, behaved themselves, learned, thanked respondents for teaching them the error of their ways, improved their behavior, reformed, and became an upstanding player/member of the community (flying in the face of Riot's real-world data, mind you), then I will at least be willing to entertain the idea that perhaps those extraordinary cases are worth the absolutely massive amount of chaff.

Fundamentally, I see no legitimate point to this challenge. Players who straighten out after a permanent ban are few and far between, and, yes, more often than not, permabanned players tend to remain belligerent and harmful to the community even after having their punishment explained to them, but _everyone_ has the right to post on PB to ask about their punishment, whether they come to accept it or Riot's rules or not.

> But if you can't, then I urge you to stop allowing permabanned toxic assholes to trash that Board, and just instantly delete any thread or comment in PB posted by a permabanned player. Don't permaban them from Boards entirely; just remove anything they post in PB.

And what'll happen then? I'll tell you - those belligerent players will see that the Moderation team is going out of their way to remove posts with any mention of the fact that they were permanently banned, even going so far as to effectively blacklist specific players from PB on that basis, and they're going to make a fuss and cry out in outrage about "Riot's Big Brother-esque censorship".

It's a lose/lose situation, and I think everyone would prefer the lesser of two evils - letting them post on PB and simply correcting them when they present false/inaccurate information is by far and away better than giving them a litany of other reasons to rant and rave across the boards.

And, even in the case that your suggestion was something that _could_ be humored, I can easily see a catch.

> If nothing else, _the time period covered by ten such posts should show us how often we see such a chimera around here_...

No matter the outcome, it looks like your challenge is set up so that you can twist it to make whatever point you want. First it could be "reformed permabanned players are too few", but then failing that, it could just as easily become "reformed permabanned players are too rare an occasion/too far between".

The condition should be singular and explicit. Ten people? Fine. But you gotta look only at the cases, not how spread out they are over time.

And, at the end of the day, this all comes back to one viewpoint distilled into a question;

> What's the point of discussing their ban, anyway? It's permanent, and Riot wants those people to quit the game.

And here's the answer;

1) Explaining to the player what behavior led to their permanent suspension.
2) Explaining to the player how the system (in the broad strokes) works.
3) Explaining the players options following a permanent suspension.
4) Being able to direct the player to the proper channels in the event that their punishment appears to be in error.
5) Building up a better understanding of the system.
6) Creating an opportunity to advise the player should they consider reform.

Riot may want those players to leave League of Legends, but ultimately, due to the nature of League as a Free-to-Play game, they can't effectively _prevent_ them from coming back. And if they _do_ come back, don't you think it'd be better if they reform, or at the very least, aren't breaking the rules anymore?

There's plenty of reason to discuss people's permanent bans. Riot's policy against overturning them and their want for those players to leave League do not diminish those reasons.

> [{quoted}](name=Umbral Regent,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=qjasOEbd,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2019-08-27T08:49:46.178+0000)
>
> Fundamentally, I see no legitimate point to this challenge. Players who straighten out after a permanent ban are few and far between, and, yes, more often than not, permabanned players tend to remain belligerent and harmful to the community even after having their punishment explained to them, but _everyone_ has the right to post on PB to ask about their punishment, whether they come to accept it or Riot's rules or not.

Right, but my point is to question whether they should have that right. I mean, they don't have the right to play the game anymore. Maybe they should also lose the right to post on PB.

> And what'll happen then? I'll tell you - those belligerent players will see that the Moderation team is going out of their way to remove posts with any mention of the fact that they were permanently banned, even going so far as to effectively blacklist specific players from PB on that basis, and they're going to make a fuss and cry out in outrage about "Riot's Big Brother-esque censorship".
> 
> It's a lose/lose situation, and I think everyone would prefer the lesser of two evils - letting them post on PB and simply correcting them when they present false/inaccurate information is by far and away better than giving them a litany of other reasons to rant and rave across the boards.

They're already crying like that about _Riot's_ "Big Brother-esque censorship" - sometimes literally, when they claim that chat restrictions infringe on their freedom of speech. Would it be the lesser of two evils to let them continue to ruin matches? Riot bans them, and they mostly don't come back. Maybe if they can't post on PB, they similarly won't come back. I think we should at least attempt to make PB not garbage.

> And, even in the case that your suggestion was something that _could_ be humored, I can easily see a catch.
> 
> No matter the outcome, it looks like your challenge is set up so that you can twist it to make whatever point you want. First it could be "reformed permabanned players are too few", but then failing that, it could just as easily become "reformed permabanned players are too rare an occasion/too far between".

You think mods shouldn't even try to find positive posts from permabanned players because I might not totally change my mind? And yet we allow those players to post, even though we might not totally change their mind, and they won't change our mind, and all that happens is a bunch of ranting and vote manipulation.

> The condition should be singular and explicit. Ten people? Fine. But you gotta look only at the cases, not how spread out they are over time.

Okay. Ten cases and I'll admit that allowing permabanned players to post on PB has enough value to hold off on removing those posts on sight (although I'll still maintain that it's trash overall). Still, people will check the dates of those threads and come to whatever conclusion that evidence supports anyway. I think you'd agree that finding ten such cases within the last week would be substantively different from having to go back to 2013, when these Boards came online.

> And, at the end of the day, this all comes back to one viewpoint distilled into a question;
> 
> And here's the answer;
> 
> 1) Explaining to the player what behavior led to their permanent suspension.
> 2) Explaining to the player how the system (in the broad strokes) works.
> 3) Explaining the players options following a permanent suspension.
> 4) Being able to direct the player to the proper channels in the event that their punishment appears to be in error.
> 5) Building up a better understanding of the system.
> 6) Creating an opportunity to advise the player should they consider reform.

And my point is that those things don't work for those players. We explain 1 and they say they didn't do anything they think is wrong, we explain 2 and they say it's a stupid system, we explain 3 and they repeat that they want their account back, 4 is just "we can't tell if you were hacked, you have to submit a ticket" (and usually they already have anyway), 5 doesn't happen with permabanned players who keep shouting that everything is unfair/rigged/etc., and 6 is flat-out incorrect, because they no longer have an account on which to reform. Riot does not want permabanned players to create new accounts. Why would we tell them to?

> Riot may want those players to leave League of Legends, but ultimately, due to the nature of League as a Free-to-Play game, they can't effectively _prevent_ them from coming back. And if they _do_ come back, don't you think it'd be better if they reform, or at the very least, aren't breaking the rules anymore?

Most permabanned players don't return. And if they do come back, I agree that it'd be better if they reform (which to me is synonymous with not breaking the rules anymore), but they _won't_. That is why they got a permaban.

> There's plenty of reason to discuss people's permanent bans. Riot's policy against overturning them and their want for those players to leave League do not diminish those reasons.

The only practical use I've seen for such discussion is when the only thing someone did was to repeat someone else's ZT phrases in an undirected fashion ("hey, don't call me a --- please"), and those cases are very rare. For the rest, I see no _practical_ reason to discuss a permaban. There are personal reasons, of course - I'm sure some people enjoy putting the smackdown on someone who brings racist/homophobic slurs to a LoL match - but that's not a practical reason, and doesn't justify the situation.

> Right, but my point is to question whether they should have that right. I mean, they don't have the right to play the game anymore. Maybe they should also lose the right to post on PB.

Bans in-game and on the boards are separate, as you well know. If they're going to be barred from posting in PB on account of having their account in-game permanently banned, then it may as well extend to the rest of the boards, too.

But, they _should_ have the right to discuss League of Legends on their account whether it's banned in-game or not. If they're banned in-game on that account, then they can no longer break the rules in-game on that account; they may still have an interest in discussing the game, or even discussing their own punishment.

If you want to strip them of their right to post on the boards, you have to have a legitimate reason that their permanent ban in-game should disqualify them that right.

> They're already crying like that about Riot's "Big Brother-esque censorship" - sometimes literally, when they claim that chat restrictions infringe on their freedom of speech.

And it would not help to give them further fuel to rant and rave harder. If they're already bad, why make them worse? Why start on a vicious cycle of squelching their opinions, making them angrier and louder, only to silence them further, making them angrier and louder...Ad infinitum?

> Riot bans them, and they mostly don't come back. Maybe if they can't post on PB, they similarly won't come back. I think we should at least attempt to make PB not garbage.

If they can't post on PB, they'll go to GD, or RANT, or Discuss the Boards, or elsewhere as long as it's a vaguely similar avenue to discuss their punishment, however fruitless.

It's much the same as the issue with indefinitely-scaling chat restrictions.

> You think mods shouldn't even try to find positive posts from permabanned players because I might not totally change my mind?

Considering that, at the end of the day, you've only the power to suggest a course of action and not implement it? They're not obligated to go searching for posts to rise to your challenge.

You want to see players whose accounts in-game are permabanned disallowed from posting in PB. This isn't even close to a good way of tackling the problem it's meant to hit - because there are people who hold strict disagreements with Riot's system and spread misinformation who _haven't_ been permanently banned.

And even if the majority of the issue lay with those permabanned players, taking such a straightforward, "get them out of here" approach would cause more harm than good, even if it _did_ solve the problem in any capacity.

> And yet we allow those players to post, even though we might not totally change their mind, and they won't change our mind...

People are allowed to maintain their opinions, even after discourse has resolved. They're allowed to be ignorant and wrong and everything else, subjective or otherwise. Even people I've largely disagreed with have held discussions that have, at the very least, made me think about shit. And some of those discussions were aggravated, heated, and uncivil; only just toeing the line of what was allowed.

We don't _need_ to change people's minds. More often than not, we _can't_. All we can do, and what we need to do, is get the right information out there and at least let it be seen. People can disagree with it, they can call it bullshit and argue against it 'till the cows come home, but so long as we get the information out, we'll have done our job.

> Okay. Ten cases and I'll admit that allowing permabanned players to post on PB has enough value to hold off on removing those posts on sight (although I'll still maintain that it's trash overall).

Believe me when I say I'm working on a list. It'll take plenty of time for me to find other cases, but it's underway.

> Still, people will check the dates of those threads and come to whatever conclusion that evidence supports anyway. I think you'd agree that finding ten such cases within the last week would be substantively different from having to go back to 2013, when these Boards came online.

I would agree, yes. But I'm a stickler for the conditions as they're laid out.

> And my point is that those things don't work for those players. We explain 1 and they say they didn't do anything they think is wrong, we explain 2 and they say it's a stupid system, we explain 3 and they repeat that they want their account back, 4 is just "we can't tell if you were hacked, you have to submit a ticket" (and usually they already have anyway), 5 doesn't happen with permabanned players who keep shouting that everything is unfair/rigged/etc....

Explaining things may not work for most people. It may only work for one in fifty, one in a hundred, one in a thousand, but so long as there's the possibility that someone will be receptive, it will be worthwhile to explain the punishment and the system to hundreds of belligerent players.

> ...and 6 is flat-out incorrect, because they no longer have an account on which to reform. Riot does not want permabanned players to create new accounts. Why would we tell them to?

If someone shows an interest in reforming and coming back to the game after a permanent suspension, I see no issue with encouraging them to do so. Yes, Riot wants people to leave when they permaban them, but - we're not Riot. As players, we are at liberty to make our own judgement calls with how we advise other players.

If I see genuine remorse and the potential for someone to reform, I'll tell them they can start afresh - hell, I might even _encourage_ it. I wouldn't see them off flying by the seat of their pants, of course, but the point remains - Riot's goal may be to have them leave, but they cannot feasibly prevent them from coming back, and it ultimately isn't against the rules for them to come back. If they choose to reform, all the power to them.

> Most permabanned players don't return. And if they do come back, I agree that it'd be better if they reform (which to me is synonymous with not breaking the rules anymore), but they won't. That is why they got a permaban.

Whether or not they'll reform isn't a certainty. Granted, a lot of players make it abundantly clear just how well their second/third/umpteenth account is going to go, but just because a person got permabanned doesn't mean they're incapable of reforming.

I've seen cases - rare though they may be - where people realized just how shitty their behavior was too little, too late. And I've seen people struggle with reforming after the fact, too. You can't be certain that just because they got a permanent suspension that they can't reform - that's like saying that anyone who spent any amount of time at Honor Level 0-1 will always be toxic and just run their account into the ground.

> For the rest, I see no practical reason to discuss a permaban. There are personal reasons, of course - I'm sure some people enjoy putting the smackdown on someone who brings racist/homophobic slurs to a LoL match - but that's not a practical reason, and doesn't justify the situation.

I think getting the information out there and learning from other peoples' mistakes to build a better understanding of how the system works are practical enough reasons to discuss permanent bans. Those are my two biggest reasons, and I figure there are at least a good couple other players on the PB boards who have similar or even different reasons to discuss those punishments as well.

You had me up until the religious part. You can do better than that.

Nor do I think removing conversations is a good idea, even if they're shitty conversations. Worth is a subjective thing.

Better than that, like "show me a statistically significant correlation between PB posts from permabanned players and good posts, within a certain time window," etc.? I think asking for a flat number is a lot simpler but still pretty useful.

Worth is subjective, but if we establish certain standards, like practical value, civil discourse, etc. - which the rules do - then it makes objective sense to remove certain kinds of conversations with little worth according to those standards. Viz, the endless rants, threadjacking, and bad advice from permabanned players.

The mods' line of reasoning on being so permissive with that sort of thread has historically been that _sometimes_ there's a positive result, and it's worth PB being 99% garbage just for the sake of those people. If that's true, then it shouldn't be much of a stretch to find some of those gems.

If it's not worth finding those threads, then the permissiveness itself isn't worth the trouble, either.

Who determines what's garbage? They remove anything that doesn't adhere to the universal rules, and anything that's a low-effort rant.

Censorship isn't good just because some people might not like the content. Nobody is forcing any of us to read or participate in any posts.

I mean, PB isn't *designed* for that, but it's a nice secondary feature we wouldn't want to lose. Similar to how **Streams & Videos** helps keep **General Discussion**, **Gameplay**, and **Concepts & Creations** free from video spam, **Concepts & Creatures** keeps **Gameplay** free of non-official suggestions, and **RANT** keeps everything slightly more free of anger posts.

It's rarely our *primary* goal (RANT aside), but it's a very strong secondary advantage that we're more than happy to admit.

I'm just going to assume you've never heard of the Starfish story:

>One day, an old man was walking along a beach that was littered with thousands of starfish that had been washed ashore by the high tide. As he walked he came upon a young boy who was eagerly throwing the starfish back into the ocean, one by one.

>Puzzled, the man looked at the boy and asked what he was doing. Without looking up from his task, the boy simply replied, “I’m saving these starfish, Sir”.

>The old man chuckled aloud, “Son, there are thousands of starfish and only one of you. What difference can you make?”

>The boy picked up a starfish, gently tossed it into the water and turning to the man, said, “I made a difference to that one!”
